Spring 2019

Vivacity Healing

UX/UI Design

‹Minds at Peace›Redwood Counseling

Challenge

Vivacity Healing needed help improving the overall look of their business to attract new clients.

Role

Redesigned brand identity and simplified website with intuitive navigation and a clean, friendly interface.

Overview

Vivacity Healing is a local start-up company in Cincinnati that specializes in reflexology and acupressure. After launching in early 2018, they wanted to attract more clients, so they came to me for help.

Goals

I approached my redesign in three steps, while conducting research throughout:

  1. Consistant brand identity
  2. Intuitive navigation
  3. Clean visual interface

Inspiration

While searching for inspiration I came across this style on Dribbble and immediately felt that it suited our new brand identity.

1. Brand identity

During my research I learned the importance of a brand’s visual presence and how the logo works to point customers to the company as a whole and reflect the relationship that organization has with their audience.

The logo is a visual brand element, which can be the start of a relationship between the business and the consumers.

My goal was to create a logo that represents the feeling that Vivacity presents to their clients.

Shape. The lotus is a clean, simple shape that represents purity of the body.

Color. The vibrant colors show excitement, clarity, warmth, cheerfulness and confidence. This is how we want clients to feel as soon as they walk through the door.

2. Navigation

I’m a firm believer that website navigation is one of the most critical pieces of UX design and one of the most important aspects of web design as a whole.

My goal was to create easy navigation that communicates effectively with potential clients as if we were talking face to face.

What impacts a websites navigation? Well I’m glad you asked.

  1. Menus
  2. Scrolling
  3. Icons
  4. Images
  5. Buttons
  6. & so much more

It was important to me that I serve visitors the right information at the right time. Doing this guides users through the Vivacity journey.

My rule of thumb for pretty much anything -- less is more. That is why I reduced the number of main navigation options. I wanted to create a menu that's ‘easy to digest’. To do this, I eliminated unnecassary clutter by using flat, linear navigation.

3. Visual interface

My main goal was to guide visitors through the site in a clear and intuitive way. From Geek Squad to my 102 year old great-grandma, browsing a site should feel 'easy-peasy' for everyone.

It was important to create a website with clear and fresh contrast. This helps customers read and understand what’s in front of them.

Non-responsive design can feel like a major headache, and there’s no reason to do that to your users.

It seems like these days everyone has a million devices -- okay maybe not a million but still people aren’t just looking at sites on their computer anymore. That’s why it is so crucial to have an interactive website that can adapt to the given resolution and device size.

Lastly, I wanted a consistent style that made it easy for users to comprehend and respond. Of course a good UI design should look great on the outside but it’s even more important to:

  1. Have a clear structure
  2. Pay attention to UX
  3. Be unique, simple, and concise

Landing page

A landing page is the first thing a user sees when they visit a website. It's also the biggest factor in determining whether they stay. To fit our new status, I gave the page a modern look.

Large shapes going off the page and gradient backgrounds are all the rage. It’s also a fresh look in an industry notorious for outdated interfaces.

Conclusion

Overall, the site proved to be a huge success but it's far from perfect. Both clients and other practitioners have complimented the site’s ease of use and appearance.

Since I created a custom look on Squarespace my client can easily update the info as her company grows. Cheers to a new website that looks and works amazingly!

That's a wrap!

You can check out more of my work on Instagram and Dribbble.
